questions.text: Shortly after delivery, a full-term male newborn is found to have black hair with a white forelock. His mother, a brunette, auditory brainstem auditory evoked responses show bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Which of the following is the most likely cause of findings in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase activity

questions.text: A 51 -year-old woman undergoes coronary angiography for chest pain. Initial electrocardiogram (ECG) performed in the emergency department shows ST elevation in leads VI,V3. Angiography findings are shown in this image. Which of the following best describes the findings?
questions.correct_answer: A. Left anterior descending artery stenosis

questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the emergency department complaining of fever, chills, and dyspnea on exertion. He admits to smoking one pack of cigarettes a day, consuming 2-3 alcoholic beverages daily, and using intravenous illicit drugs 2-3 times per week. He is febrile and tachycardic. Blood cultures grow Staphylococcus aureus. A diagnosis of infective endocarditis is established. The valve most likely affected in this patient can be best evaluated by auscultation in which of the following areas?

A 42-year old man comes to the office with rectal bleeding. He used to have occasional streaks of blood on the tissue after wiping but for the past several days he has seen blood dipping into the toilet bowl at the end of defecation. The patient gives a history of chronic constipation and has to strain during defecation but has na rectal or abdominal pain. He works as a truck driver and his diet consists mainly of unhealthy foods. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. There is no mass or tenderness on digital rectal examination, but anoscopy shows bulging purplish-blue mucosal lesions above the dentate line. Rubber band ligation of the lesions is most likely to involve which of the following?

A 36-year-old man is rushed to the emergency department after the sudden onset af shortness of breath and difficulty swallowing. He has visited the emergency department several times before for food and skin allergies. He is unconscious on Examination shows excessive accessory respiratory muscle use and edematous swelling of his face. lips, and tongue. There is scattered urticaria over his upper body. Attempts at intubation are unsuccessful due the massive soft tissue edema involving his pharynx. A decision is made to perform an emergency cricothyrotomy. The incision made during this procedure will most likely pass through which of the following structures?
questions.correct_answer: D. Superficial fascia and cricothyroid membrane

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after falling from a chair onto an outstretched arm. Her mother believes that she hyperextended her arm. Physical examination shows swelling of the right elbow and tenderness to palpation over the distal humerus. Radial pulses are full and symmetric bilaterally. The patient is unable to cooperate with neurologic examination of the right hand du. to significant pain. A peripheral intravenous line is placed and opiate analgesics are administered for pain control. X-rays show a supracondylar humeral fracture with anterolateral displacement of the proximal fracture fragment. Which of the following structures is at greatest risk for injury in this patient?

A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with seven right hip pain after a fall. She was walking down a hallway when she pipped on a rug and fell against a wall and then to the floor, landing on her hip. The patient has a history of depression and Polymyalgia rheumatica. Current medications include sertraline and low-dose prednisone. She also has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg and pulse is 96/min. The patient appears to be in significant pain. She is unable to move the right hip, and the right leg appears shorter than the left. A pelvic x-ray is shown in the image below: Injury involving which of the following arteries is most likely to lead to osteonecrosis in this patient?

A 29-year-old previously healthy man comes to the hospital wtUI a right leg injury acer a cycling accident. He reports pain in the lower log and inability to bear weight. X-ray reveals right Tibial and fibular shaft fractures. The parent undergoes closed reduction and immobilization of he fractures. Several hours later. he has increasingly severe pain in his right leg. Physical examination shows increased tension within the anterior compartment. Which of the following structures is most likely to be compromised by this parent's acute complication?

Cultured fibroblasts taken from an infant suffering from hypotonia and seizures show an Impaired ability to oxidize very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) and phytanic acid. The detect is most likely localized to:?

A 35-year-old female is hospitalized with headaches and vomiting. She has a long history of psychiatric illness and known to practice eccentric dietary habits. Physical landings include papilledema, dry skin and hepatosplenomegaly. Head CT scan is ordered immediately but is negative for intracranial mass. Which of the following is a likely the cause of this patient's condition?

A 42-year-old woman comes to the neurologist for enrollment in a research study. She has a 15-year history of resting tremor. bradykinesia. and cogwheel rigidity cons-stent with Parkinson disease. One of her siblings recently started having similar symptoms. Genetic analysis is permitted on the patient and her affected sibling. The results show a loss-of-function mutation in a gene that leads to an accumulation of misfolded proteins. Which of the following biochemical processes is most likely defective in this patient?
Which of the following blocks the enzyme complex II in the given figure?

An 18.month-old boy is brought to the office due to language regression. He said several words at his 1 year appointment but now no longer speaks any words at all. His moods have also become more unpredictable over the past 4 months with frequent tantrums. The parents tried to bring him in sooner for evaluation, but they live in an unimproved shed part of the city and experienced financial difficulties with transportation to the office. On physical examination the boy is quiet and maintains appropriate eye Contact throughout the visit. Hemoglobin is 9 g/dl. Which of the following enzymes is most likely Inhibited in hls patient?
A schematic structure of tRNA is shown on the slide below. Which of the following sites is responsible for amino acid binding?

A 35-year-old previously healthy man is evaluated for several episodes of syncope in the past 6 weeks. Physical examination is unremarkable. Echocardiogram shows no structural heart defect.An electrophysiologic study is performed during which catheters are passed into the patient's right and left atrium to record atrial electric potentials. Cardiac marker currently shows normal sinus rhythm. Which of the following is the most likely earliest site of electric activation?

options.label: A
options.text: Junction of left atrium and atrial appendage

options.label: B
options.text: Left atrium near the opening of pulmonary veins

options.label: C
options.text: Right atrium near the opening of inferior vena cava

options.label: D
options.text: Right atrium near the opening of superior vena cava

questions.correct_answer: D. Right atrium near the opening of superior vena cava

questions.text: A 54-year-old man is evaluated for episodic abdominal discomfort, bloating sensation, flatulence. and occasional diarrhea He has no blood in the stool or weight loss. The parent has avoided dairy products, but the symptoms did not improve. On examination, there is mild epigastric tenderness on deep palpation. Stool occult blood testing is positive. Histopathological evaluation of hyperemic mucosa seen during gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals hyperplasia of branched, tubular submucosal glands containing alkaline secretions. Which of the following areas is the most likely finding biopsy in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: B. First part of the duodenum

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy experiences excessive bleeding following a tooth extraction. His Past medical history includes episodes of painful joint swelling from minor trauma. Physical examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen with a liver span of 10 cm. The spleen is not palpable. Laboratory results are as follows: • Bleeding time- 5 min • Activated partial thromboplastin- 25 sec • Prothrombin time- 23 sec This patient most likely has a deficiency involving which of the following factors?

A 52-year-old man comes to the physician with concerns about a "heart problem". He feels fine, but was told to see a physician after a heart murmur was detected during a wellness fair at work. Physical examination reveals a holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex of the heart that radiates to the axilla. The remainder of his physical examination is normal. Which of the following is the best indicator of the severity of this patient's problem?

A 34-year-old comes to the physician with a 2-month history of exertional dyspnea and progressive lower extremity swelling. He also reports abdominal distension and decreased appetite. The patient has gained 4.5 kg over the last 2 months. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and recurrent lung infections requiring prolonged antibiotic therapy. He has no history of coronary artery disease. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 1 5 years. He undergoes noninvasive cardiac testing followed by cardiac catheterization. A jugular venous pressure tracing is shown on the slide below. The waveform indicated by the arrow most likely corresponds to which of the following?

A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because he and his wife have been unable to conceive for the last 2 years. They have no children. Infertility evaluation is begun, and laboratory studies show a low sperm count A more borough evaluation elucidates a rare genetic abnormality that leads to permanently inactive FSH receptors. Which of the following substances most likely decrease in this patient?

Skeletal muscle biopsy is performed on a 1 7-year-old male with proximal muscle weakness. No abnormalities are found on light microscopy. Electron microscopy of The specimen reveals no T-tubules in some muscle fibers. Which of the following is The most likely consequence of the observed finding in the affected muscle cells?

options.label: A
options.text: No contraction in response to intracellular Ca

options.label: C
options.text: Poor force generation on repeated stimulation

options.label: D
options.text: Impaired relaxation after a single contraction

questions.text: Scientists are attempting to study the specifics of kidney function in humans. They begin by studying the concentrations of various compounds along the length of the proximal tubules in human kidneys. They are able to measure the concentrations of several substances over the length of a proximal tubule. Tubular fluid/plasma ultrafiltration concentration ratios for several substances hey wore able to measure are shown on the slide below: Which of the following substances are most likely to produce cures 2 and 4,respectively?

A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by paramedics following a high-speed motor vehicle accident. Several attempts are made to resuscitate him but are unsuccessful. The patient had no significant past medical history and took no medications. He was known to be in good health and tolerant of moderate levels of physical activity. Electrocardiogram findings at his last office visit showed no abnormalities. At autopsy, heavy calcifications of the aortic valve are seen as shown in the image. Which of the following most likely preceded the aortic valve changes observed in this patient?

A 30-year-old man presents with a 1-week history of malaise,red eyes, swelling of his ankles, and red, tender nodules on the shins. He is not receiving any medications and has no prior medical or surgical history. On examination he has a temperature of 39°C, the skin findings shown in the illustration, synovitis of both ankles, and red eyes. Laboratory examination includes the chest radiographic findings shown below. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 64-year-old woman presents for evaluation of recent onset of fatigue and weakness. She has noted difficulty doing her usual activities but is not very specific about this. On examination,she has the constellation of skin findings shown in the illustrations and some mild upper extremity weakness. Which tumor is most likely associated with this scenario?

A 28-year-old woman complains of a 3-week history of palpitations and shakiness. She attributes her insomnia to her new baby, born 5 weeks previously. On examination there is increased sweating, a fine tremor of outstretched hands, and a small non tender goiter. Laboratory investigations show TSH < 0.002mIU/L and free thyroxine 2.1 ng/dL (0.8-1.8). She is breastfeeding. Which one of the following investigations is indicatedto help establish the diagnosis?

A 70-year-old man complains of diarrhea and four episodes of arthritis over the past 3 months. His family thinks he is becoming more forgetful. On examination, he appears hyperpigmented and has generalized lymphadenopathy. Fecal fat is 20 g/24 h.Small-bowel biopsy specimens show periodic acid-Schiff(PAS)–positive/acid-fast–negative granules in macrophages in lamina propria of the small intestine. The most likely cause of this patient’s illness is:

options.label: A
options.text: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection withMycobacteriumavium-intracellulare complex (MAC) of the small bowel

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents to your office for a routine annual examination. His history is significant for 7 years of mild ulcerative colitis that has been well controlled with mesalamine alone. He has no family history of colon cancer or polyps. Thepatient is at increased risk of each of the following except:

At an annual examination, a 58-year-old asymptomatic woman has elevated liver enzymes. She has a history of diabetes mellitus, for which she uses metformin. She drinks one small glass of wine daily but denies prior blood transfusions,needlestick exposures, illicit drug use, and family history of liver disease. Physical examination findings are notable for a body mass index of 38 kg/m2. Laboratory tests are notable for ALT 84 U/L, AST 63 U/L, glycosylated hemoglobin 5.3%, low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol 180 mg/dL,and triglycerides 240 mg/dL. Anti–hepatitis C virus (HCV),hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), and serum iron study results are negative or normal. Antinuclear antibody (ANA)is positive at a titer of 1:40, anti–smooth muscle antibody is negative, and ?-globulin is 1.0 g/dL. Ultrasonography of the right upper quadrant is notable for changes in liver echotexture consistent with fat and gallbladder stones without gallbladder wall thickening. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old veterinarian states that he is stressed because his grandson has mental retardation due to fragile X syndrome and will be moving to a group home. The man has noted a tremor and problems with his memory and is concerned that this may be related to the fragile X syndrome in his family.What do you do?

options.label: A
options.text: Assure him this is impossible because fragile X is inherited as an X-linked trait.

options.label: B
options.text: Assure him this is impossible because he is of normal intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: Assure him his symptoms are related to stress.

options.label: D
options.text: Order a molecular analysis for fragile X.

questions.correct_answer: D. Order a molecular analysis for fragile X.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with confusion, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. A CBC documented a hemoglobin con-centration of 8.5 g/dL and a normal MCV. The peripheral blood smear revealed the findings as shown below. The platelet count was 8 ×109/L. The patient had a prothrombin time and activated partial thromboplastin time that were normal. The urinalysis revealed +2 protein. The serum creatinine was 3.0 mg/dL.What is the treatment of choice?

options.label: B
options.text: Platelets, cryoprecipitate, and fresh frozen plasma

options.label: D
options.text: Plasmapheresis with replacement with fresh frozen plasma

questions.correct_answer: D. Plasmapheresis with replacement with fresh frozen plasma

questions.text: A 58-year-old man had a radical retropubicprostatectomy. Postoperatively, the hemoglobin concentration decreased from 11 to 9.6 g/dL. He received transfusions with red blood cells,fresh frozen plasma, and cryoprecipitate. However, the hemoglobin decreased to 6.6 g/dL. The PT was 15 seconds (normal < 12.0 seconds) and an international normalized ratio (INR) was 1.5. The fibrinogen was decreased at 58 mg/dL. What is the treatment of choice?

options.label: A
options.text: Transfusion with erythrocytes, platelets, fresh frozen plasma, and cryoprecipitate

options.label: B
options.text: Transfusion with red blood cells and platelets

options.label: C
options.text: Transfusion with erythrocytes and platelets, with heparin administered intravenously

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with fever, lymphadenopathy,and a 20-lb weight loss. A biopsy revealed the findings shown in the image below. A CT scan of the chest revealed a mediastinal mass with pulmonary nodules. A CT scan of the abdomen revealed lymphadenopathy in the cervical, mediastinal, and abdominal locations. The bone marrow revealed no evidence of disease.What is the treatment of choice?
questions.correct_answer: C. ABVD (Adriamycin, bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine)

questions.text: A 75-year-old man was evaluated in consultation for multiple medical problems. He was being treated with unfractionated heparin for a recent deep venous thrombosis. Which one of the following sets of laboratory study results is most consistentwith full doses of heparin?

options.label: A
options.text: Normal PT, APTT, thrombin time (TT), fibrinogen, and bleeding time

options.label: C
options.text: Abnormal PT, APTT, TT, and fibrinogen

options.label: D
options.text: Slightly abnormal PT, abnormal APTT, abnormal TT,normal fibrinogen, and normal or abnormal bleeding time

options.label: E
options.text: Abnormal APTT and TT only in all cases

questions.correct_answer: D. Slightly abnormal PT, abnormal APTT, abnormal TT,normal fibrinogen, and normal or abnormal bleeding time

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents with nocturia 3 times nightly. You Diagnose benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and initiate treatment with terazosin after educating the patient about BPH.Which one of the following statements about the natural history of BPH would not be true?

options.label: A
options.text: The majority of men older than age 60 have BPH.

options.label: B
options.text: BPH results from growth of epithelial and stromal cells.

options.label: C
options.text: There is no evidence to indicate that BPH progresses over time.

options.label: D
options.text: Urine flow obstruction may lead to detrusor hypertrophy and bladder contractions.

questions.correct_answer: C. There is no evidence to indicate that BPH progresses over time.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman complains of double vision while reading in the evening- She first noticed the double vision several months ago, but her symptoms have gotten worse over the last 2 weeks. Who has also developed difficulty chewing and avoids eating tough foods like steals She has no extremity weakness or sensory complaints and notes that her symptoms are significantly improved after rest. The patient is started on appropriate treatment and reports significant improvement of her symptoms. However, she now complains of abdominal cramping, nausea. sweating, and diarrhea. Which of the following agents can be used to effectively control his new symptoms?

A 22-year-old man presents with a 10-year history of recurrent angioedema, particularly of the lips and eyes. He has had throat swelling on three occasions. These episodes seem to occur randomly, approximately monthly, and there is no association with food, medications (including over-the-counter medications), or environmental exposures. Interestingly, his father reports having similar symptoms for years. The patient is healthy otherwise. Physical examination findings are normal,although he brings in photos showing marked angioedema of the orbits and lips. The medication to treat this patient’s dis-order is:

You are consulted about a 35-year-old woman who has been evaluated by her gynecologist. She is 12 weeks pregnant. She has a blood pressure of 160/88 mm Hg in both arms in the seated position. Findings on cardiac examination are a tapping apical impulse with a normal first heart sound, normal physiologically split second and fourth heart sounds, and nonsignificant murmurs. Which one of the following medicationsdo you recommend for control of blood pressure?

options.label: A
options.text: Enalapril 5 mg orally twice a day

options.label: B
options.text: Metoprolol 100 mg orally twice a day

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg orally twice a day

options.label: D
options.text: No pharmacologic medical management (blood pressure probably will decrease when she is out of the office)

questions.correct_answer: C. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg orally twice a day

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient is being treated for atrial fibrillation with an antiarrhythmic drug. He suddenly becomes diaphoretic and syncopal, and the electrocardiogram shown below is obtained.Which one of the following is the most likely drug that was being administered to the patient?

A 55-year-old woman with a 20-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus is referred for management of osteoporosis, diagnosed after a wrist fracture. Bone mineral density revealed T scores of ?3.6 at the femoral neck and ?3.2 at the lumbar spine. Her history is remarkable for significant dyspepsia, incompletely controlled on proton pump inhibitors. Levels of serum calcium parathyroid hormone (PTH), 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25-OH-D), and bone-specific alkaline phosphatase are normal. Which of the following would be the ideal first-line treatment in this case?

options.label: E
options.text: Vitamin D and calcium supplementation alone

questions.text: A 52-year-old man has had diabetes for 10 years. He has no known complications and has been treated with glyburide and metformin. He has a known history of hyperlipidemia and is taking aspirin (325 mg) and simvastatin (20 mg) daily in addition to his antidiabetic medications. Lipid-lowering therapy was instituted 1 year ago. At his annual examination, he has the following laboratory results: fasting glucose 170 mg/dL,hemoglobin A1c 7.5% (4.0-6.3%), TSH 5.5 mIU/L, creatinine 1.3 mg/dL, cholesterol 240 mg/dL, triglycerides 250mg/dL, HDL 25 mg/dL, and calculated LDL 165 mg/dL.Which treatment is most likely to achieve a beneficial decrease in cholesterol?

options.label: A
options.text: Add a resin such as cholestyramine or colesevelam.

questions.correct_answer: A. Add a resin such as cholestyramine or colesevelam.

questions.text: A23-year-old woman presents with 3 weeks of diarrhea and left lower quadrant discomfort. Her diarrhea is described as three or four loose, nonbloody stools per day. She denies any fevers,chills, nausea, or vomiting, and her appetite has been normal.Stool cultures are negative for pathogens, and no parasites are seen. She undergoes colonoscopy that is notable for mildmucosal erythema and granularity that extends uninterrupted from the anal verge to the cecum. The terminal ileum is spared.Biopsy specimens demonstrate chronic crypt architectural changes as well as mild acute inflammation. What therapy would you recommend for this woman?

Hypertension is diagnosed in a 65-year-old woman. An anti-hypertensive medication is thought to be warranted for her treatment. Her only other medical problem is urinary stress incontinence. Which of the following antihypertensive medications has the potential to worsen her incontinence?

A 3-year old girl is brought to the office after developing fever and a sore throat. The patient recently entered day care and similar symptoms have been reported in several of the other children. Physical examination shows exudative pharyngitis and enlarged anterior cervical lymph nodes A rapid antigen detection test confirms he diagnosis of streptococcal throat infection. Her condition resolves with antibiotic therapy. Several weeks later, she is re-exposed to Streptococcus pyogenes. The bacteria penetrating beyond the surface epithelium are immediately coated with performed lgG antibodies. Which of the following substances acts in the most similar manner to lgG antibodies to facilitate phagocytosis?

A 38-year-old man is undergoing treatment for acute myelogenous leukemia. Initially, he complained of fevers and being lethargic and fatigued all the time. However, of late, he has noted increasingly severe right-sided headaches. He describes pain is throbbing in nature and located behind his right eye, which is also associated with nasal stuffiness. The patient denies any previous history of allergies. Physical examination reveals right-sided proptosis and periorbital tenderness. Biopsy of the right maxillary sinus mucosa reveals the following: Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condhon?

A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to the sudden onset of high fever and shaking chills. Twelve hours before the presentation, he had experienced shortness of breath and cough. The patient has smoked A pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His vaccination record is unknown. Examination shows dullness to percussion over the left side of the chest. Chest x-ray reveals consolidation in the left upper lobe. Gram stain of the sputum shows gram-positive diplococci. Small a-hemolytic colonies grow in a blood agar plate. Which of the following is the major virulence factor of the bacteria causing the disease in this patient?

A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to a 2-day history of high fever, headache, mild confusion, and dry cough. She also has mild abdominal discomfort and watery diarrhea. The patient recently returned from a cruise to Hawaii. Her other medical problems include hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She has smoked A pack of cigarettes daily for over 20 years. Her temperature is 40 C (104 F), blood pressure is 104/63 mm Hg, pulse is 85/min, and respirations are 24/min. Lung examination reveals lower lobe crackles with no wheezing. Her abdomen is soR, non-distended, and non-tender. Chest x-ray shows bilateral lower lobe interstitial infiltrates. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Gram-positive diplococci in sputum Gram stain

options.label: D
options.text: Positive polymerase chain reaction assay for influenza A RNA

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician due to malaise and cough over the past 2 months. He describes yellow sputum production with occasional streaks of blood. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and has a history of alcohol abuse with prior episodes of binge dunking. Temperature is 37.1 C (98.8 F). Examination shows poor dentition with dental caries, gingivitis, and enlarged submandibular lymph nodes. Coarse rhonchi are heard over the right upper lung lobe. Chest CT is notable for an extensive right upper lung consolidative process with air bronchograms. Bronchoscopy is performed, and a lung biopsy specimen shows the following findings

Gram-negative coccobacilli isolated from the CSF of an infant with meningitis demonstrate little growth on sheep agar but grow well once incubated on the same media which Staphylococcus aureus. Staphylococci promote the growth of the bacteria by supplementing:

A 4-year old boy is brought to the physician by his mother with decreased appetite, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea over the last 3 days. The stools wore inhale watery but have now become bloody. On physical examination, his temperature is IO0.4 F [38 C). There are signs of dehydration and he has a mild distended abdomen with diffuse pain elicited on palpation. Stool studies are positive for fecal leukocytes and blood. Fecal cultures grow non lactose fermenting, gram-negative rods that ferment glucose without gas production, on MacConkey agar. The bacteria generate hydrogen sulfide when grown on triple sugar iron agar, and cannot replicate at refrigeration temperatures. Which of the following bacterial factors is the most important during the pathogenesis of this parent'8 disease?

A 10-year-old child presents with diarrhea and abdominal pain for 4 days. Stool microscopy was done and is shown below. The eggs present in the stool are found to float in a saturated solution of salt. Which of the following can be used for the treatment of this?
What is the time since death in the below image in a body found dead in summers in India?

A 27 year old man's body has been brought in for autopsy. He was allegedly speeding on the highway, when the lorry ahead of him had suddenly braked and the man had run into the tail-board of the lorry with his bike. On impact he was thrown backward and landed on his head. With the knowledge of these incidents, where would the forensic doctor suspect the contrecoup fracture to be located at most probably?
Identify the range.
Which of the following is true for the poisoning caused by this substance?

options.label: A
options.text: Is a competitive antagonist of GABA.

options.label: B
options.text: This poisoning is characterized by conscious seizures.

options.label: C
options.text: Fatal dose is one crushed seed

options.label: D
options.text: Death is not associated with postmortem caloricity.

questions.correct_answer: B. This poisoning is characterized by conscious seizures.

questions.text: You work in an ambulatory clinic. You want to identify each of your patients who might have had an acute pulmonary embolism (PE). Therefore, you use a clinical probabilityassessment tool as part of your diagnostic algorithm for patients with suspected PE. With this assessment tool, if the responses to all questions are negative, the estimated prevalence of PE is only 10%. You also know that a D-dimer enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) has a sensitivity of 95% and a specificity of 50% for the diagnosis of PE in an ambulatory care setting. If you used this ELISA D-dimer test as part of your algorithm to clarify the diagnosis in this low-prevalence group, what percentage of that group who test positive would actually have a confirmed PE?

A well-done randomized trial evaluated the efficacy of full-dose subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) versus warfarin (international normalized ratio [INR], 2.0-3.0) in reducing recurrent venous thromboembolism (VTE) in a group of patients with VTE and active cancer. The study duration was 6months. During that time, 17% of the cancer patients receiving warfarin had recurrent VTE compared with 9% of patients receiving full-dose subcutaneous LMWH. On the basis of this information, how many patients need to be treated for 6 months with subcutaneous LMWH to prevent one additional VTE?

A 55-year-old man comes into the urgent care clinic at your medical facility with a hand laceration. He accidentally cut his finger with a kitchen knife while preparing to slice vegetables.He has a 1.5-cm laceration on the palmar surface of his left middle finger, overlying the proximal phalanx. Flexor tendon and vascular structures are intact. He has no record of prior tetanus vaccinations but believes that he probably had “baby shots” because his mother was a nurse. He served in the army and recalls getting many vaccinations while in basic training. He cannot recall getting any vaccinations since leaving military service. You clean and suture the laceration. Which of the following do you recommend for tetanus prophylaxis?

options.label: A
options.text: No tetanus prophylaxis because this is a clean, minor wound

questions.text: The headquarters of the following organization is situated at which place?

The fasting blood glucose levels of a hypothetical population form two overlapping distributions,one of the people with diabetes(B) and another people with no diabetes(A).A test was done and the cutoff was designed to be 120mg/dl.What does area “C” represent in the given image?

options.label: A
options.text: Diabetics correctly classified as the same.

options.label: B
options.text: Non diabetics correctly classified as the same

options.label: C
options.text: Non diabetics incorrectly classified as diabetics

questions.correct_answer: D. Diabetics incorrectly classified as non-diabetics

questions.text: A smoker states that he has been smoking for 6 years. In the first year, he was smoking up to 5 sticks per day. In the next 3 years he increased it to half pack per day. In the 5th year, it went up to 1 pack per day (20 cigarettes). In the last year, he stated that he smoked 2 packs per day. From the following pick the correct mean, median and mode, respectively, of the number of sticks.
The mean blood alcohol levels are measured in patients before and after using an interventional drug. The statistical test of significance applied is?

A farmer brought his 16-month-old child to the OPD for routine immunization. He has been adequately immunized until now. He has already received a measles vaccine during an SIA drive (supplementary immunization activity) a few months back. What will you administer now?

options.label: A
options.text: OPV booster, DPT booster and Vitamin A

options.label: B
options.text: OPV Booster, DPT booster, MR, JE and Vitamin A

options.label: C
options.text: OPV booster, DPT booster, JE vaccine and Vitamin A

options.label: D
options.text: OPV Booster, DPT booster, MR and Vitamin A

questions.correct_answer: B. OPV Booster, DPT booster, MR, JE and Vitamin A

questions.text: The following will include which of these vaccine preventable diseases?
All of the following health disorders are covered under Child Health Screeningand Early Intervention Program (RBSK) except
According to the biomedical waste management guidelines,you would dispose your used face shield in which of the following bins?
The Oxford University developed Astra Zeneca(Covishield),acts through which mechanism?
Which of the following is recommended for cleaning and disinfecting a healthcare facility against COVID 19?
The first component that is removed while doffing of a PPE kit is?
Case acts as its own control in which of the following study?

A 54-year-old woman is evaluated for a painless thyroid nodule. She has no weightchanges, heat or cold intolerance, hoarseness, or dyspnea Past medical history is notable only for mild hypertension, for which she takes appropriate medications. The patient does not use tobacco or alcohol. Physical examination shows a 3-cm, amt nodule in the right thyroid lobe and enlarged, right cervical lymph nodes. Her TSH is normal, and fine-needle aspiration of the nodule shows papillary structures with nuclear atypia. Total thyroidectomy is planned. During the surgery, a nearby nerve is injured while ligating an artery entering the superior pole of the thyroid lobe. Which of the following muscles is most likely to be denewated as a result of this injury?

A 51 -year-old woman comes to the physician complaining that the right side of her face has felt 'funny ' fo4 the past 12 hours. Her past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Physical examination reveals asymmetry of her face when she smiles, puffs out her cheeks. and closes her eyes tightly. There is also effacement of the right nasolabial fold, and her mouth is drawn toward the left side. Which of the following additional findings is most likely associated with this patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Attenuated sense of touch on the right side of face

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased tearing from the right eye

options.label: C
options.text: Failure to elevate the palate when saying 'ah'

options.label: D
options.text: Inability to sweat on the right side of face

questions.correct_answer: B. Decreased tearing from the right eye

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parerQs due to persistent nasal bleeding. The boy picks his nose frequently and has had several nosebleeds in past all of which stepped spontaneously Beer pinching he The parents say that they have been pinching the nasal dae for over 30 minutes while the boy leans forward. Family history is negative far bleeding disorders. The patient takes no medications and has no allergies. Examination shows continuous blood pickle from his right nostril. Silver nitrate cauvery is performed and th. bleeding stops. Cautery was most likely applied to which of the following locations in this patient's nasal cavity?

A 54.year-old woman comes to the clinic due to difficulty hearing for the past few weeks. During the neurologic examination, the physician assesses her hearing using a vibrating tuning fork, the handle of the tuning fork is placed on her left mastoid process until the sound is no longer audible. The tunes are then quickly placed near the patient's left auditory meatus, and she reports hearing no sound. When the handle of the vibrating fork is placed on the middle of her forehead, she hears the vibration more strongly in her left ear than her right. This patient is most likely experiencing which of the following types of hearing loss?
questions.correct_answer: B. Conducive loss in left ear

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine follow-up appointment. He has a 20-pack-year smoking history and recently began chewing tobacco. He drinks 6-1 0 beers each weekend. The patient's past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. His last hemoglobin A,.was 8.3%. His body mass index is 27.5 kg/m:. On oral examination: a white patch is seen on the buccal mucosa. The lesion appears to have a granular texture; is not indurated, and is not removed by scraping with a tongue depressor. There is no regional lymphadenopathy.Which of the following is the most likely cause of the oral lesion in this patient?

A 30-year-old school teacher presents with a three-day history of fever, chills: and sore throat. He also complains of difficulty swallowing that started yesterday. He denies any cough, chest pain: or difficulty breathing. He is married and denies any new sexual encounters. His temperature is 39.8' C (102.2' F): blood pressure is 1 18/76 mmhg: pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 19/min. On examination: his voice is muffled. Enlarged: tender cervical lymph nodes are palpated on the left, and his uvula is deviated to the right. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

A 78-year-old woman comes to the physician with a week-long history of worsening left-sided ear pain and drainage. The pain is unrelenting but it is especially severe at night and is exacerbated by chewing. She reports a sense of fullness in the ear and mild hearing loss on the left side. The patient's past medical history is significant far hypertension: type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include lisinopril, a statin, and metformin. She has missed her last 2 appointments with her primary care physician. Her temperature is 38.3 C (IOI F), blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, and pulse is 98/min. On examination, the left external auditory canal is edematous with purulent discharge and granulation tissue in the flaocThe tympanic membrane is clear. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 89 mm/h. An ear swab is obtained. Which of the following is the best initial treatment for this patient?
The following instrument is used for all except-
Treatment of choice for this condition?

A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with worsening fever and sore throat. Four days ago, the patient accidentally swallowed a fish bone that scratched her throat and caused some discomfort. She felt better after some time and did not seek medical attention: but for the past 2 days she has had severe sore throat and difficulty swallowing. The patient also reports neck pain and stiffness. Her temperature is 39 C (102.2 F): blood pressure is 1 26/80 mm Hg: and pulse is 1 06/min. Examination shows pooling of saliva in the hypopharynx. The posterior pharyngeal wall is red and bulging. The neck is stiff with reduced passive range of motion. Lung auscultation is normal. Lateral radiographs of the neck reveal increased thickness of the prevertebral soft tissues with an air-fluid level. Due to potential contiguous spread of the disease process: this patient is at greatest risk of developing which ofthe following?

33-year-old recovery room nurse discovers her right pupil to beseveral millimeters larger than her left pupil. She denies diplopia, but she has had several headachesin the past week.Her right pupil does not react to light, but otherwise the examination is normal. The next diagnostic step would be:

A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to left eye pain after being involved in a street fight. He received a fist blow to the left eye and has since had pain and diplopia. Past medical history is notable for 2 previous gunshot wounds. The patient does not smoke cigarettes but has a history of heavy alcohol intake and frequent manjuana use. On examination, bore is significant soft tissue swelling around the left eye. Visual acuity is normalbut extraocular motility of the left the eye is limited. Pupillary reflexes are normal. Coronal CT scan of the orbits is shown in the image below: The orbital contents of this patient are most likely to herniate into which of he following sites?
A 58-year-old Type 2 Diabetes mellitus patient man is referred to you because of a sign in the retina found on routine ophthalmologic examination. What is false regarding this sign?

options.label: A
options.text: The sign is better appreciated on red free light

options.label: C
options.text: Seen in early stages of Diabetic retinopathy

questions.text: A 1 7-year old boy is brought to the clinic due to poor vision at night- The patient developed mild difficulty seeing at night about 4 months ago, and it has slowly worsened. Visual field examination shows visual loss in the midperiphery. External eye examination reveals normal tear formation. Funduscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc pallor, attenuation of retinal vessels, and areas of dark discoloration in the retina. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient's visual impairment?

options.label: D
options.text: Poor aqueous outflow due to narrow angle

questions.text: A 22-year old woman comes to the office for a routine prenatal visit. She is 16 weeks pregnant with her first child. Two months ago, she had a mononucleosis-like illness with fever, myalgia, and fatigue, and she was diagnosed with cytomegalovirus infection. The patient recovered with symptomatic treatment and is currently asymptomatic. Her other medical problems include episodic migraine headaches and benign choroidalnevus. She takes prenatal vitamins and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. The patient has a family history of hypertension and glaucoma. Physical examination findings and prenatal ultrasound are unremarkable. This patient's unborn infant is at greatest risk for which of the following eye conditions?

A 3-month-old boy is brought to the office by his mother for a routine checkup- He is found to have a right-sided white pupillary reflex. His father was diagnosed with a retinal neoplasm during childhood and had his left eye enucleated. This child is at the greatest risk of developing which of the following neoplasms?

A 63-year-old known to have poorly controlled type-2 diabetes presented to the ophthalmologist on call complaining of floaters and decreased vision. The ophthalmologist has recommended that the patient has treatment for proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) but has also referred the patient to the medical team for a review of the patient's diabetic control. In their referral note, the ophthalmologist has written that the patient has the 'usual ' signs seen with PDR in the eye. Which of these clinical signs does NOT fit with this description?

A 65-year old man comes to the emergency department due to a sudden loss of vision in his right eye. He has had diabetes: and has been heated with metformin and glyburide for the past 10 years. Visual acuity is reduced to light perception in his right eye: and normal in his left. His vital signs are normal. Ophthalmoscopy reveals loss of fundus details, floating debris and a dark red glow What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old homeless man presents to your office with reports of decreased vision and pain in his right eye for the past 2 days. Examination reveals marked conjunctival injection, a 2-mm hypopyon, and dense vitreous opacities on B-scan ultrasound. You suspect endogenous endophthalmitis, and on further questioning, the patient admits to IV drug abuse. Given the patient’s history, which one of the following organisms is the most likely to be involved in this patient’s endophthalmitis?

A 4-year-old girl is brought to the office by her parents due to frequent squinting of the left eye. That eye also seems more prominent than the right: according to the mother The child was born full term after a normal pregnancy and delivery. Developmental milestones have been age appropriate. Left eye examination reveals mild proptosis: esotropia: and optic disc pallor. Visual acuity is decreased in the left eye but is normal in the right. There are several large cafe-au-lait macules and marked axillary freckling. Which ofthe following is the most likely cause of this patient's ocular findings?

A 60-year-old previously healthy man notices that his eyes are yellow and he has been losing weight. On physical examination the patient has jaundice and scleral icterus with a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant. Abdominal ultrasound demonstrates biliary ductal dilation without gallstones. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the workup of this patient?

A 32-year-old alcoholic with end-stage liver disease has been admitted to the hospital 3 times for bleeding esophageal varices. He has undergone banding and sclerotherapy previously. He admits to currently drinking a 6 pack of beer per day. On his abdominal examination, he has a fluid wave. Which of the following is the best option for long-term management of this patient’s esophageal varices?

options.label: B
options.text: Transection and reanastomosis of the distal esophagus

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with no history of use of NSAIDs presents with recurrent gastritis. The patient was diagnosed and treated for H. pylori 6 months ago. EGD at that time was normal. Which of the following tests provides the least invasive method to document eradication of the infection?

A 45-year-old woman has an incidental finding of a (2 cm) liver mass on a CT scan done for workup after a road traffic accident . Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is suggestive of a hemangioma. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Percutaneous biopsy of the lesion to confirm the diagnosis

questions.text: An ultrasound is performed on a patient with right upper quadrant pain. It demonstrates a large gallstone in the cystic duct but also a polypoid mass in the fundus. Which of the following is an indication for cholecystectomy for a polypoid gallbladder lesion?

options.label: C
options.text: Patient age of older than 25 years

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with sudden onset of massive, painless, recurrent hematemesis. Upper endoscopy is performed and reveals bleeding from a lesion in the proximal stomach that is characterized as an abnormally large artery surrounded by normal-appearing gastric mucosa. Endoscopic modalities fail to stop the bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate surgical management of this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Wedge resection of the lesion with truncal vagotomy

options.label: C
options.text: Wedge resection of the lesion with highly selective vagotomy

options.label: D
options.text: Wedge resection of the lesion with truncal vagotomy and antrectomy

questions.correct_answer: A. Wedge resection of the lesion

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with pain in the left leg after walking more than one block that is relieved with rest. On physical examination, distal pulses are not palpable in the left foot and there is dry gangrene on the tip of his left fifth toe. An ankle-brachial index on the same side is 0.5. Which of the patient’s symptoms or signs of arterial insufficiency qualifies him for reconstructive arterial surgery of the left lower extremity?

A 53-year-old man who has had angina as well as claudication reports feeling light-headed on exertion, especially when lifting and working with his arms. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of his symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Antegrade flow through a vertebral artery

options.label: B
options.text: Venous congestion of the upper extremities

questions.correct_answer: C. Occlusion of the subclavian artery

questions.text: A 25 -year-old woman is evaluated for acute abdominal pain that began 6 hours ago. The pain was initially localized to the umbilical area but has now migrated to the right lower quadrant. After the onset of pain, she developed anorexia and vomited once. Medical history is unremarkable. The patient has regular menstrual periods, and her most recent period ended 2 days ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses oral contraceptives. On physical examination, temperature is 39.0°C (102 .3°F), blood pressure is 120/90 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 100/min. Abdominal examination reveals normal bowel sounds and tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Pelvic examination discloses tenderness on the right side but no adnexal enlargement or masses. There is no cervical or vaginal discharge or cervical motion tenderness. The leukocyte count is 10,000/µL (10 x 109/L) . Urinalysis shows 20 to 30 leukocytes/high-power fields without bacteria. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old man is re-evaluated after undergoing upper endoscopy for acid reflux symptoms. The patient has a 15-year history of acid reflux symptoms that occur after meals and at night. He has a 30-pack-year history of smoking and continues to smoke one pack of cigarettes daily. Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy for reflux symptoms was started 6 weeks ago. His symptoms resolved while he was taking the PPI but returned when he discontinued therapy. He has since resumed taking the PPL Because of continuing symptoms, upper endoscopy was performed. Endoscopic biopsy specimens showed the following image . Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

A 32-year-old man presents with an asymptomatic mass in his right testicle. On examination, the mass cannot be transilluminated. Ultrasound shows a solid mass in the right testicle. Chest, abdomen, and pelvis CT scans are negative for metastases. Serum levels of alpha-fetoprotein and beta human chorionic gonadotropins are elevated. Which of the following is the next best step in his diagnostic workup?

options.label: C
options.text: Incisional biopsy of the testicular mass through a scrotal incision

options.label: D
options.text: Excisional biopsy of the testicular mass through a scrotal incision

questions.text: A 45-year-old otherwise healthy woman presents with a 7-cm renal cell carcinoma without radiologic evidence of abdominal lymph node involvement and with no distant metastases. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

A 55-year-old man presents with fever and pain in the perineal region. Upon further questioning he also complains of frequency, urgency, dysuria, and a decreased urinary stream. On physical examination, his abdomen is soft, nondistended, and nontender. Digital rectal examination demonstrates exquisite tenderness on the anterior aspect. Laboratory examination reveals leukocytosis and findings on urinalysis are consistent with a bacterial infection. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32 -year-old man sustains head trauma in a motor vehicle collision. He has a GCS of 15 and an obvious closed, depressed skull fracture. Which of the following is NOT an indication for surgical intervention?
A neonate is examined in the nursery and found to have no anal orifice; only a small perineal fistulous opening is visualized. Which of the following is associated with this abnormality?

A newborn infant born with polyhydramnios presents with excessive salivation along with coughing and choking with the first oral feeding. An x-ray of the abdomen shows gas in the stomach and a nasogastric tube coiled in the esophagus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: C. Esophageal atresia and tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF)

questions.text: An 86-year-old man is evaluated after a recent diagnosis of prostate cancer. He developed significant urinary hesitancy, and a prostate examination showed an enlarged prostate with a right-sided nodule. A subsequent biopsy revealed adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6. He reports no bone pain, weight loss, fever, chest pain, or shortness of breath. His medical history is notable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he takes antihypertensive and diabetic medications. On physical examination, his vital signs are normal. No lymphadenopathy is noted. His lungs are clear to auscultation, and his abdomen is soft, with normal bowel sounds. Except for his prostate findings, the remainder of his physical examination is unremarkable. Prostate-specific antigen level is 6.4 ng/mL (6.4 µg/L) . Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

An 18-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis. With the presumptive diagnosis of appendicitis, a right lower quadrant (McBurney) incision is made and a lesion 60 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve is identified (see photo). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An otherwise healthy 31-year-old male presents with a painless bulge in his right groin. Although it does not bother him or limit his daily activities, he notices fluctuation in its size, from being absent when he lies at or a few minutes, to a golf -ball sized mass upon coughing or strenuous exercises. Physical examination confirms the presence of right inguinal hernia. No abnormalities were noted on the contralateral side.After an open inguinal hernia repair, which symptom is likely to appear as a result of the most commonly injured nerve in this type of approach?

options.label: A
options.text: Numbness on ipsilateral upper lateral thigh

options.label: C
options.text: Hyper response o the cremasteric re ex

questions.correct_answer: B. Numbness on ipsilateral medial thigh

questions.text: You are called to the delivery room to assist in management of the delivery of child with a known anterior abdominal wall defect and maternal polyhydramnios. Regarding the pathophysiology of pediatric abdominal wall defects, which of the following is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Polyhydramnios and intestinal atresia are not associated with omphalocele or gastroschisis.

options.label: B
options.text: Gastroschisis is more commonly associated with cardiac and chromosomal anomaliesthan omphalocele.

options.label: C
options.text: A gastroschisisis more likely to be associated with Beckwith Wiedemann syndrome than omphalocele.

options.label: D
options.text: Herniated liver indicates the defect is most likely an omphalocele.

questions.correct_answer: D. Herniated liver indicates the defect is most likely an omphalocele.

questions.text: Which of the following is true of transfusion related acute lung injury (TRALI)?

options.label: B
options.text: It is caused by anti-HLA-antibodies in blood products that activates recipient leukocytes.

options.label: C
options.text: Acute respiratory illness arises within 2 days of transfusion of blood products.

options.label: D
options.text: Is easy to differentiate from acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

options.label: E
options.text: It is not associated with the number of transfusions or the age of blood

questions.correct_answer: B. It is caused by anti-HLA-antibodies in blood products that activates recipient leukocytes.

questions.text: A 67-year-old female presents with sharp, burning right upper quadrant abdominal pain that radiates to her back. The pain awakens her from sleep.She has experienced nausea and three episodes of emesis. She reports burning substernal and epigastric pain. She denies any fevers or chills. She is hemodynamically normal and afebrile. Her abdominal exam is remarkable or mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant without peritoneal signs. After three hours, her pain resolves.What is the next best test in this patient’s scenario?
Regarding breast reconstruction options, which of the following is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Autologous tissue reconstruction is preferred whenever possible over implant reconstruction.

options.label: B
options.text: If implant reconstruction is desired, tissue expanders will be placed at the time of mastectomy and final implants will be placed 4 to 6 weeks later.

options.label: C
options.text: Reconstruction does not significantly interfere with the detection of recurrent disease.

options.label: D
options.text: Smoking is an absolute contraindication or autologous tissue reconstruction.

options.label: E
options.text: Autologous and implant reconstruction can significantly delay subsequent adjuvant therapy.

questions.correct_answer: C. Reconstruction does not significantly interfere with the detection of recurrent disease.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of hemorrhage sources and preferred management are correct ?

options.label: A
options.text: Junctional hemorrhage— tourniquet placed directly over the injury

options.label: B
options.text: Extremity hemorrhage—Hemostatic dressing and direct pressure

options.label: C
options.text: Truncal hemorrhage—Permissive hypotension and hemostatic resuscitation

options.label: D
options.text: Pelvic hemorrhage—Early use of Factor VIIa

questions.correct_answer: C. Truncal hemorrhage—Permissive hypotension and hemostatic resuscitation

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is evaluated for a 3-day history of left lower quadrant abdominal pain. He rates the pain as 6 on a scale of l to 10. His appetite is decreased, but he is able to tolerate oral intake. He is otherwise healthy and has had no previous gastrointestinal problems. On physical examination, temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F) , blood pressure is 138/78 mm Hg, pulse rate is 103 /min, and respiration rate is 14/min. Abdominal examination discloses focal tenderness in the left lower quadrant. There is perirectal fullness. Laboratory studies reveal a hemoglobin level of 13.5 g/dL (135 g/L) and a leukocyte count of 14,000/µL (14 x 109/L) . Urinalysis is normal. Computed tomographic scan of the abdomen and pelvis discloses moderately dense diverticula in the descending colon and proximal sigmoid colon; focal bowel wall thickening (5 mm) in the mid sigmoid colon with associated inflammation of the pericolic fat; and no evidence of ileus, obstruction, abscess, or perforation. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
Match each description with the most appropriate type of obstetric anesthesia.Each lettered option may be used once, more than once, or not at all.
Select the most appropriate diagnosis for each clinical situation described. Each lettered option may be used once, more than once, or not at all.

A 23-year-old G1 at 39 weeks’ gestation presents to triage with a chief complaint of uterine contractions. They began 2 hours ago, are painful, and occur every 4 to 8 minutes. She reports good fetal movement, and no bleeding or leaking fluid. There are contractions every 5 to 15 minutes. The fetal monitor shows a category 1 tracing. On examination, her cervix is 1-cm dilated, 60% effaced, and the fetal vertex is at -1 station. The patient had the same cervical examination in your office last week. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Admit her for an epidural for pain control

questions.text: A 35-year-old G2P1 at 39 weeks’ gestation presents to labor and delivery in active labor. Her cervix is 5-cm dilated and 80% effaced, and the vertex is at 0 station. she is having contractions every 3 minutes. The fetal heart tracing shows a baseline rate of 140 beats per minute, moderate variability, with accelerations and no decelerations. One hour after she is admitted, her membranes rupture spontaneously. Shortly thereafter, she develops recurrent variable decelerations. What is the best next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue to monitor, as variable decelerations do not require intervention

options.label: C
options.text: Since she is remote from delivery, perform a cesarean

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. Her last menstrual period (LMP) was 8 weeks ago, and her pregnancy test is positive. Her blood pressure is 85/65 mm Hg and her pulse is 110 beats per minute. On examination, her abdomen is distended and tender. A bedside abdominal ultrasound shows free fluid within the abdominal cavity. The decision is made to take the patient to the operating room for emergency exploratory laparotomy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old primigravid woman, who plans to breastfeed, decides to have a home delivery. Immediately after the birth of a 4.1-kg newborn, the patient experiences massive hemorrhage from extensive vaginal and cervical lacerations. She is brought to the nearest hospital in shock. Over the course of 2 hours, nine units of blood are transfused, and the patient’s blood pressure returns to a reasonable level. A hemoglobin value the next day is 7.5 g/dL, and three more units of packed red blood cells are given. The most likely late sequela to consider in this woman is which of the following?

A 30-year-old G5P3 has undergone a repeat cesarean delivery. She wants to breastfeed. Her past medical history is significant for hepatitis B infection, hypothyroidism, depression, and breast reduction. She is receiving intravenous antibiotics for endometritis. The baby latches on appropriately and begins to suckle. . In the mother, which of the following is a response to newborn suckling?

The patient returns to see you in 6 weeks for a routine postpartum visit. She has been nursing her baby without any major problems, and wants to continue to do so for at least 9 months. She is ready to resume sexual activity and wants to know what her options are for contraception. She is a nonsmoker, and her only other medication is a prenatal vitamin. Which of the following methods may decrease her milk supply?

On postpartum day 2 after a vaginal delivery, a 32-year-old G2P2 develops acute shortness of breath and chest pain. Her vital signs are: blood pressure 120/80 mm Hg, pulse 130 beats per minute, respiratory rate 32 breaths per minute, and temperature 37.6°C (99.8°F). She has new onset of cough. She appears to be in mild distress. Lung examination reveals clear bases with no rales or rhonchi. The chest pain is reproducible with deep inspiration. Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia with 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 88% on room air, and oxygen supplementation is initiated. Which of the following is the best diagnostic tool to confirm the diagnosis?

A 38-year-old G2P1 comes to hospital for her first ANC visit at 10 weeks’ gestation. She had a previous term vaginal delivery without any complications. You detect fetal heart sounds at this visit, and her uterine size is consistent with dates. You also order routine prenatal laboratory tests, which return showing that her blood type is A(? ) , and she has a positive anti- body screen, with an anti-D antibody titer of 1:4. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Schedule an amniocentesis for amniotic fluid bilirubin at 16 weeks

options.label: D
options.text: Schedule percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS) to determine fetal hematocrit at 20 weeks.

questions.correct_answer: B. Repeat the titer in 4 weeks

questions.text: A 33-year-old G2P1 is undergoing an elective repeat cesarean section at term. The newborn is delivered without any difficulties, but the placenta cannot be removed easily because a clear plane between the placenta and uterine wall cannot be identified. The placenta is removed in pieces. This is followed by uterine atony and hemorrhage.

A healthy 59-year-old woman with no history of urinary incontinence undergoes vaginal hysterectomy with anterior and posterior (A&P) repair for uterine prolapse, a large cystocele, and a rectocele. Two weeks postoperatively, she presents to your office with a new complaint of intermittent leakage of urine. What is the most likely cause of this complaint following her surgery?

A 65-year-old woman presents to your office for evaluation of pelvic organ prolapse (POP). Her past medical history is significant for chronic hypertension, which is well controlled with a calcium channel blocker. She also has chronic constipation which requires use of a laxative to have a bowel movement. She has smoked for over 30 years, and has a chronic cough. She entered menopause at the age of 52 years, but has never taken hormone replacement therapy. Her obstetric history includes three term vaginal deliveries. Her last baby weighed 9 lb, and required a forceps delivery. The delivery was complicated by a large tear that involved the vagina and rectum. Which of the following factors is least important in the subsequent development of POP in this patient?

A 30-year-old G3P3 is being evaluated for urinary urgency, frequency,and dysuria. She also reports post-void dribbling of urine and insertional dyspareunia. Her history is significant for recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) as a teenager, but no other medical problems. She has had three term spontaneous vaginal deliveries, and her last baby weighed over 9 lb. She recalls having a vaginal laceration requiring multiple sutures after delivery of that child. On pelvic examination, she has a 1-cm tender suburethral mass. Palpation of the mass results in expression of a small amount of blood-tinged purulent discharge. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s problem?

You evaluate a 39-year-old G2P2 on postoperative day 2 following a difficult abdominal hysterectomy for endometriosis. Her surgery was complicated by hemorrhage from the left uterine artery pedicle that required multiple sutures to control bleeding. Her estimated blood loss was 500 mL. Her only other medical problem is obesity, and her prior surgeries are two cesarean deliveries. The patient now has fever, left back pain, left costovertebral angle tenderness, and hematuria. Her vital signs are height 5 ft 2 in, weight 250 lb, temperature 38.2°C (100.8°F), blood pressure 110/80 mm Hg, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, and pulse 102 beats per minute. Her postoperative hemoglobin dropped from 11.2 g/dl to 9.8 g/dl, her white blood cell count is 9.5 L, and her creatinine rose from 0.6 mg/dL to 1.8 mg/dL. What is next best step in the management of this patient?

A 21-year-old woman presents to your office for her well-woman examination. She has recently become sexually active and desires an effective contraceptive method. She has no medical problems, but family history is significant for breast cancer in a maternal aunt at the age of 42 years. She is worried about getting cancer from taking birth control pills. You discuss with her the risks and benefits of contraceptive pills. You tell her that which of the following neoplasms has been associated with the use of oral contraceptives?

A 35-year-old G2P2 presents for a contraceptive counseling visit. She and her husband desire a long-term contraceptive method, and are uncertain if they want more children. She has been happily married for 10 years. Her only medical problem is mild hypertension, for which she takes a diuretic, and she has never had a sexually transmitted disease. She is considering the copper IUD and wants to know how it works. Which of the following mechanisms does not potentially contribute to the mechanism of the action of the copper IUD?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased tubal motility inhibits ovum transport.

options.label: B
options.text: An inflammatory response within the endometrium damages the fertilized ovum.

options.label: C
options.text: Premature endometrial sloughing associated with menorrhagia causes early abortion.

options.label: D
options.text: An inflammatory response within the endometrium kills sperm.

questions.correct_answer: C. Premature endometrial sloughing associated with menorrhagia causes early abortion.

questions.text: A 21-year-old G0 presents to hospital because her menses is 2 weeks late. She states that she is taking her birth control pills correctly; she may have missed a day at the beginning of the pack, but took it as soon as she remembered. She has no medical problems, but 3 weeks ago she had a “viral stomach flu,” and missed 2 days of work due to nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Her cycles are usually regular, even without oral contraceptive pills. She has been on the pill for 5 years, and recently developed some midcycle bleeding, which usually lasts about 2 days. She has been sexually active with the same partner for the past 3 months, and has a history of chlamydia 3 years ago. She has had a total of 10 sexual partners. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Which of the following is the major cause of unplanned pregnancies in women using oral contraceptives?
questions.correct_answer: C. Incorrect use of oral contraceptives

questions.text: A 31-year-old female presents to her physician complaining of rapid onset of hirsutism, deepening of the voice, irregular menses, clitoral enlargement, and acne. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this clinical presentation?

A 34-year-old woman presents to establish primary care. Her past Pap smear was 3 years ago and showed normal cytology and negative testing for human papilloma virus (HPV). She had two abnormal Pap smears in the past, at age 21 and 22 (both with atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance). She has had regular Pap smears since that time with normal cytology. Which of the following would represent an acceptable approach to screening for cervical cancer in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Repeat cytology and HPV cotesting in 2 years.

questions.text: Which of the following should be the next investigation in a patient presenting with primary amenorrhea and normal secondary sexual characteristics
A 7 year old girl comes for routine checkup as her mother noticed grape like mass protruding from childs vagina. The folwoing is the examination finding what is the possible diagnosis
To decrease the risk of perinatal vertical transmission, breastfeeding should be avoided in patients with:
Which of the following agents can be used to aid in uterine relaxation when managing a uterine inversion?

A 9-year-old boy presents with pain in both heels for 3 months. He has also been to the GP with a painful red eye on several occasions. On examination he has an effusion in his left knee, decreased range of movement in his right hip, and tenderness along the Achilles, tendons and heel. His erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 100 mm/h;C reactive protein 45 (7); full blood count normal; human leukocyte antigen (HLA) B27 positive.What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. Systemic onset juvenile idiopathic arthritis

questions.text: A female newborn is born at 39 weeks' gestation following an uneventful pregnancy The Apgar scores are 10 at 1and 5 minutes, respectively. The newborn is at the 50th Features. The parents are told she has an enzyme defect that, if left untreated, will result in failure to attain early developmental milestones, microcephaly, hyperactivity, seizures, intellectual disability and a mousy odor of the skin and the urine.The patients diet need to contain which of the following substance to provide the substrate for catecholamine production?

A 12-month-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for an upperrespiratory infection. His temperature is 38.3 C (IOI F), blood pressure is 92/45mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 25/min. Physical examination reveals erythema and swelling of the nasal mucosa and nasal discharge. Cardiac auscultation findings at the left sternal border are a continuous murmur. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A collection of tan fat-containing tissue is found around the kidneys and adrenal glands of a newborn during surgery. Surgical removal of the tissue would most likely contribute to:

A 12 year old boy presents with seizures to the casualty.On history, mother reveals previous episodes of hospitalization for seizures which were difficult to control with medication. CT scan shows the following diagnosis-
The given image shows a micturatingcystourethrogram of a three year old boy.Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the most common cause of severe obstructive uropathy in children.

options.label: B
options.text: Both males and females are affected.

options.label: C
options.text: Antenatal USG would have shown oligohydramnios.

options.label: D
options.text: Transurethral ablation of leaflets can be done.

questions.correct_answer: B. Both males and females are affected.

questions.text: A well 3-week-old baby boy,at term is referred to hospital with severe respiratory failure. There is no periumbilical swelling or erythema. There is a small redness at the site of cord separation, which is discharging a small amount of yellow fluid. The GP had taken a swab which grew Staphylococcus epidermidis. The MOST appropriate course of action is which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Reassure patents and review in weeks

questions.correct_answer: A. Reassure patents and review in weeks

questions.text: A girl infant has profound hypotonia and requires intubation and positive pressure ventilation immediately after birth. She was born at term following a pregnancy complicated by polyhydramnios and reduced fetal movements. The Chest X-ray shows small, but clear, lung fields. What is the MOST likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old boy presents with a 3-week history of fever and being miserable. His mother says he has been complaining of generalized aches and pains and malaise especially in the right leg and has now developed a limp. He has recently been on holiday in Manali. X-ray of The tibia shows periosteal elevation. Initial investigations are asfollows; haemoglobin 10 g/dl (10.5- 1 4 g/dl); WBC 17 x 109/1, (6- 15 x 109/L) lymphocytes 4 x 109/L; neutrophils 13 x 109/L; eosinophils 2 x 109/L; urea 3 mmol/L (2.5-6.6 mmol/L) ; creatinine 45 pmol/L (20-80pmol/L);ALT 30 IU/L (I 0-40 IU/L); normal; APTT normal; CRP.25 (( 5 mg/dl); ESR 60( 20 mm/hour).What is the most likely diagnosis for the above condition?
A woman develops chickenpox 2 days before giving birth to a healthy term baby. Which of the following is the treatment of choice?

options.label: A
options.text: NO treatment necessary for mother or baby

options.label: B
options.text: Treat mother with varicella zoster immune globulin only

options.label: C
options.text: Treat baby with varicella zoster immune globulin only

options.label: D
options.text: Treat baby with varicella zoster immune globulin and aciclovir ifchickenpox develops

questions.correct_answer: D. Treat baby with varicella zoster immune globulin and aciclovir ifchickenpox develops

questions.text: DIF examination of perilesional tissue involved with pemphigus vulgaris reveals deposition of:

options.label: A
options.text: IgA in a linear pattern along the dermoepidermal junction

options.label: B
options.text: IgA in a granular pattern along the dermoepidermal junction

options.label: C
options.text: IgG in a net-like pattern within the epidermis

options.label: D
options.text: IgG in a net-like pattern within the dermis

questions.correct_answer: C. IgG in a net-like pattern within the epidermis

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, currently 30 weeks pregnant with her second child, presents with 2 months of worsening centrofacial hyperpigmentation. This pigmentation was initially noted during her last pregnancy, but no treatment has yet been initiated. Which of the following would be the most appropriate initial treatment regimen?

options.label: B
options.text: Sunscreen, topical tretinoin, and topical hydroquinone

options.label: D
options.text: Sunscreen, topical hydroquinone, and topical steroids

questions.text: A man with leprosy came with the following lesion. What is the type of leprosy?
A patient came with itchy tense blisters on normal skin as well as over urticarial plaques as shown in the figure . What is the diagnosis?
Match the following -
You are presented with a patient with eye pain that's worsened by eye movement and Vision loss. You are suspecting optic neuritis. Investigation of choice in optic neuritis is :-

options.label: D
options.text: MRI brain and Orbit with gadolinium contrast enhancement

questions.correct_answer: D. MRI brain and Orbit with gadolinium contrast enhancement

questions.text: As an intern on duty, you are discussing the investigations with the patient and below shown image is shown to you. Identify the investigation

A 32-year-old man with Crohn’s disease reports increased perianal pain and swelling over a 2-month period. On examination, there is a small perineal sinus lying at the 3 O’clock position in relation to the anus. On MRI, a fistulous track of high T2 signal is seen to pass from the anal canal, through the internal sphincter and then runs medial to the external sphincter. The track reaches physical examination. Which description best describes this anal fistula?
You are shown chest radiograph of a 49-year-old man with cough. Which one of the following is the MOST likely diagnosis?
A patient with a history of atrial fibrillation presents with 1 hour of right-sided hemiparesis. Which of the following is MOST sensitive for acute cerebral infarction?
